Accelerated Stochastic ExtraGradient: Mixing Hessian and Gradient Similarity to Reduce Communication in Distributed and Federated Learning

Dmitry Bylinkin
MIPT
dbylinkin69@gmail.com â€ƒâ€ƒ Kirill Degtyarev
MIPT
degtiarev.kd@phystech.su â€ƒâ€ƒ Aleksandr Beznosikov
MIPT, ISP RAS, Innopolis University
beznosikov.an@phystech.su
Abstract

Modern realities and trends in learning require more and more generalization ability of models, which leads to an increase in both models and training sample size. It is already difficult to solve such tasks in a single device mode. This is the reason why distributed and federated learning approaches are becoming more popular every day. Distributed computing involves communication between devices, which requires solving two key problems: efficiency and privacy. One of the most well-known approaches to combat communication costs is to exploit the similarity of local data. Both Hessian similarity and homogeneous gradients have been studied in the literature, but separately. In this paper, we combine both of these assumptions in analyzing a new method that incorporates the ideas of using data similarity and clients sampling. Moreover, to address privacy concerns, we apply the technique of additional noise and analyze its impact on the convergence of the proposed method. The theory is confirmed by training on real datasets.

1Â Â Introduction

Empirical risk minimization is a key concept in supervised machine learning (Shalev-Shwartz etÂ al.,, 2010). This paradigm is used to train a wide range of models, such as linear and logistic regression (Tripepi etÂ al.,, 2008), support vector machines (Moguerza and MuÃ±oz,, 2006), tree-based models (Hehn etÂ al.,, 2020), neural networks (Sannakki and Kulkarni,, 2016), and many more. In essence, this is an optimization of the parameters based on the average losses in data. By minimizing the empirical risk, the model aims to generalize well to unseen samples and make accurate predictions. In order to enhance the overall predictive performance and effectively tackle advanced tasks, it is imperative to train on large datasets. By leveraging such ones during the training process, we aim to maximize the generalization capabilities of models and equip them with the robustness and adaptability required to excel in challenging real-world scenarios (Feng etÂ al.,, 2014). The richness and variety of samples in large datasets provides the depth needed to learn complex patterns, relationships, and nuances, enabling them to make accurate and reliable predictions across a wide range of inputs and conditions. As datasets grow in size and complexity, traditional optimization algorithms may struggle to converge in a reasonable amount of time. This increases the interest in developing distributed methods (Verbraeken etÂ al.,, 2020). Formally, the objective function in the minimization problem is a finite sum over nodes, each one containing its own possibly private dataset. In the most general form, we have:

minxâˆˆâ„dâ¡[râ€‹(x)=1Mâ€‹âˆ‘m=1Mrmâ€‹(x)=1Mâ€‹âˆ‘m=1M(1nmâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nmâ„“â€‹(x,yjm))],subscriptğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘¥1ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ‘¥1ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ‘€1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘šâ„“ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—ğ‘š\min_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\left[r(x)=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{m=1}^{M}r_{m}(x)=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{m=1}^{M}\left(\frac{1}{n_{m}}\sum_{j=1}^{n_{m}}\ell(x,y_{j}^{m})\right)\right], (1)

where Mğ‘€M refers to number of nodes/clients/machines/devices, nmsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘šn_{m} is the size of the mğ‘šm-th local dataset, xğ‘¥x is the vector representation of a model using dğ‘‘d features, yjmsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—ğ‘šy_{j}^{m} is the jğ‘—j-th data point on the mğ‘šm-th node and â„“â„“\ell is the loss function. We consider the most computationally powerful device that can communicate with all others to be a server. Without loss of generality, we assume that r1subscriptğ‘Ÿ1r_{1} is responsible for the server, and the rest rmsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šr_{m} for other nodes.

This formulation of the problem entails a number of challenges. In particular, transferring information between devices incurs communication overhead (Sreenivasan etÂ al.,, 2006). This can result in increased resource utilization, which affects the overall efficiency of the training process. There are different ways to deal with communication costs (McMahan etÂ al.,, 2017; Koloskova etÂ al.,, 2020; Alistarh etÂ al.,, 2017; Beznosikov etÂ al.,, 2023). One of the key approaches is the exploiting the similarity of local data and hence the corresponding losses. One way to formally express it is to use Hessian similarity (Tian etÂ al.,, 2022):

â€–âˆ‡2rmâ€‹(x)âˆ’âˆ‡2râ€‹(x)â€–â‰¤Î´,normsuperscriptâˆ‡2subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ‘¥superscriptâˆ‡2ğ‘Ÿğ‘¥ğ›¿\|\nabla^{2}r_{m}(x)-\nabla^{2}r(x)\|\leq\delta, (2)

where Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0 measures the degree of similarity between the corresponding Hessian matrices. The goal is to build methods with communication complexity depends on Î´ğ›¿\delta because it is known that Î´âˆ¼1/nâˆ¼ğ›¿1ğ‘›\delta\thicksim\nicefrac{{1}}{{\sqrt{n}}} for non-quadratic losses and Î´âˆ¼1/nâˆ¼ğ›¿1ğ‘›\delta\thicksim\nicefrac{{1}}{{n}} for quadratic ones (Hendrikx etÂ al.,, 2020). Here nğ‘›n is the size of the training set. Hence, the more data on nodes, the more statistically "similar" the losses are and the less communication is needed. The basic method in this case is Mirror Descent with the appropriate Bregman divergence (Shamir etÂ al., 2014a, ; Hendrikx etÂ al.,, 2020):

xk+1=argâ¡minxâˆˆâ„dâ¡(r1â€‹(x)+âŸ¨âˆ‡râ€‹(xk)âˆ’âˆ‡r1â€‹(xk),xâŸ©+Î´2â€‹â€–xâˆ’xkâ€–2).subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘¥âˆ‡ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜âˆ‡subscriptğ‘Ÿ1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘¥ğ›¿2superscriptnormğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜2x_{k+1}=\arg\min_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\left(r_{1}(x)+\langle\nabla r(x_{k})-\nabla r_{1}(x_{k}),x\rangle+\frac{\delta}{2}\|x-x_{k}\|^{2}\right).

The computation of âˆ‡râˆ‡ğ‘Ÿ\nabla r requires communication with clients. Our goal is to reduce it. The key idea is that by offloading nodes, we move the most computationally demanding work to the server. Each node performs one computation per iteration (to collect âˆ‡râˆ‡ğ‘Ÿ\nabla r on the server), while server solves the local subproblem and accesses the local oracle âˆ‡r1âˆ‡subscriptğ‘Ÿ1\nabla r_{1} much more frequently. While this approach provides improvements in communication complexity over simple distributed version of Gradient Descent, there is room for improvement in various aspects. In particular, the problem of constructing an optimal algorithm has been open for a long time (Shamir etÂ al., 2014b, ; Arjevani and Shamir,, 2015; Yuan and Li,, 2020; Sun etÂ al., 2022a, ). This has recently been solved by the introduction of Accelerated ExtraGradient (Kovalev etÂ al.,, 2022).

Despite the fact that there is an optimal algorithm for communication, there are still open challenges: since each dataset is stored on its own node, it is expensive to compute the full gradient. Moreover, by transmitting it, we lose the ability to keep procedure private (Weeraddana and Fischione,, 2017), since in this case it is possible to recover local data. One of the best known cheap ways to protect privacy is to add noise to communicated information (Abadi etÂ al.,, 2016). To summarize the above, in this paper, we are interested in stochastic modifications of Accelerated ExtraGradient (Kovalev etÂ al.,, 2022), which would be particularly resistant to the imposition of noise on the transmitted packages.

2Â Â Related Works

Since our goal is to investigate stochastic versions of algorithms that exploit data similarity (in particular, to speed up the computation of local gradients and to protect privacy), we give a brief literature review of related areas.

2.1Â Â Distributed Methods under Similarity

In 201420142014 the scalable DANE algorithm was introduced (Shamir etÂ al., 2014b, ). It was a novel Newton-type method that used ğ’ªâ€‹((Î´/Î¼)2â€‹logâ¡1/Îµ)ğ’ªsuperscriptğ›¿ğœ‡21ğœ€\mathcal{O}\left(\left(\nicefrac{{\delta}}{{\mu}}\right)^{2}\log\nicefrac{{1}}{{\varepsilon}}\right) communication rounds for Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex quadratic losses by taking a step appropriate to the geometry of the problem. This work can be considered as the first that started to apply the Hessian similarity in the distributed setting. A year later Î©â€‹(Î´/Î¼â€‹logâ¡1/Îµ)Î©ğ›¿ğœ‡1ğœ€\Omega\left(\sqrt{\nicefrac{{\delta}}{{\mu}}}\log\nicefrac{{1}}{{\varepsilon}}\right) was found to be the lower bound for communication rounds under the Hessian similarity (Arjevani and Shamir,, 2015). Since then, extensive work has been done to achieve the outlined optimal complexity. The idea of DANE was developed by adding momentum acceleration to the step, thereby reducing the complexity for quadratic loss to ğ’ªâ€‹(Î´/Î¼â€‹logâ¡1/Îµ)ğ’ªğ›¿ğœ‡1ğœ€\mathcal{O}\left(\sqrt{\nicefrac{{\delta}}{{\mu}}}\log\nicefrac{{1}}{{\varepsilon}}\right) (Yuan and Li,, 2020). Later, Accelerated SONATA achieved ğ’ªâ€‹(Î´/Î¼â€‹log2â¡1/Îµ)ğ’ªğ›¿ğœ‡superscript21ğœ€\mathcal{O}\left(\sqrt{\nicefrac{{\delta}}{{\mu}}}\log^{2}\nicefrac{{1}}{{\varepsilon}}\right) for non-quadratic losses by the Catalyst acceleration (Tian etÂ al.,, 2022). Finally, there is Accelerated ExtraGradient, which achieves ğ’ªâ€‹(Î´/Î¼â€‹logâ¡1/Îµ)ğ’ªğ›¿ğœ‡1ğœ€\mathcal{O}\left(\sqrt{\nicefrac{{\delta}}{{\mu}}}\log\nicefrac{{1}}{{\varepsilon}}\right) communication complexity using ideas of the Nesterovâ€™s acceleration, sliding and ExtraGradient (Kovalev etÂ al.,, 2022).

Other ways to introduce the definition of similarity are also found in the literature. In (Khaled etÂ al.,, 2020), the authors study the local technique in the distributed and federated optimization and Ïƒsâ€‹iâ€‹m2=1Mâ€‹âˆ‘m=1Mâ€–âˆ‡rmâ€‹(xâˆ—)â€–2superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘š21ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ‘€superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥2\sigma_{sim}^{2}=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{m=1}^{M}\|\nabla r_{m}(x_{*})\|^{2} is taken as measure of gradient similarity. Here xâˆ—subscriptğ‘¥x_{*} is the solution to the problem (1). This kind of data heterogeneity is also examine in (Woodworth etÂ al.,, 2020). The case of gradient similarity of the form â€–âˆ‡rmâ€‹(x)âˆ’âˆ‡râ€‹(x)â€–â‰¤Î´normâˆ‡subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ‘¥âˆ‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¥ğ›¿\|\nabla r_{m}(x)-\nabla r(x)\|\leq\delta is discussed in (Gorbunov etÂ al.,, 2021). Moreover, several papers use gradient similarity in the analysis of distributed saddle point problems (Barazandeh etÂ al.,, 2021; Beznosikov etÂ al.,, 2021; Beznosikov and Gasnikov,, 2022; Beznosikov etÂ al.,, 2022).

2.2Â Â Privacy Preserving

A brief overview of the issue of privacy in modern optimization is given in (Gade and Vaidya,, 2018). In this paper, we are interested in differential privacy. In essence, differential privacy guarantees that results of a data analysis process remain largely unaffected by the addition or removal of any single individualâ€™s data. This is achieved by introducing randomness or noise into the data in a controlled manner, such that the statistical properties of the data remain intact while protecting the privacy of individual samples (Aitsam,, 2022). Differential privacy involves randomized perturbations to the information being sent between nodes and server (Nozari etÂ al.,, 2016). In this case, it is important to design an algorithm that is resistant to transformations.

2.3Â Â Stochastic Optimization

The simplest stochastic methods, e.g. SGD, face a common problem: the approximation of the gradient does not tend to zero when searching for the optimum (Gorbunov etÂ al.,, 2020). The solution to this issue appeared in 2014 with invention of variance reduction technique. There are two main approaches to its implementation: SAGA (Defazio etÂ al.,, 2014) and SVRG (Johnson and Zhang,, 2013). The first one maintains a gradient history and the second introduces a reference point at which the full gradient is computed, and updates it infrequently. The methods listed above do not use acceleration. In recent years, a number of accelerated variance reduction methods have emerged (Nguyen etÂ al.,, 2017; Li etÂ al.,, 2021; Kovalev etÂ al.,, 2020; Allen-Zhu,, 2018).

The idea of stochastic methods with variance reduction carries over to distributed setup as well. In particular, stochasticity helps to break through lower bounds under the Hessian similarity condition. For example, methods that use variance reduction to implement client sampling are constructed. Catalyzed SVRP enjoys ğ’ªâ€‹((1+Mâˆ’1/4â‹…Î´/Î¼)â€‹log2â¡1/Îµ)ğ’ª1â‹…superscriptğ‘€14ğ›¿ğœ‡superscript21ğœ€\mathcal{O}\left(\left(1+M^{-\nicefrac{{1}}{{4}}}\cdot\sqrt{\nicefrac{{\delta}}{{\mu}}}\right)\log^{2}\nicefrac{{1}}{{\varepsilon}}\right) complexity in terms of the amount of server-node communication (Khaled and Jin,, 2022). This method combines stochastic proximal point evaluation, client sampling, variance reduction and acceleration via the Catalyst framework (Lin etÂ al.,, 2015). However, it requires strong convexity of each rmsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šr_{m}. It is possible to move to weaker assumptions on local functions. There is AccSVRS that achieves ğ’ªâ€‹((1+Mâˆ’1/4â‹…Î´/Î¼)â€‹logâ¡1/Îµ)ğ’ª1â‹…superscriptğ‘€14ğ›¿ğœ‡1ğœ€\mathcal{O}\left(\left(1+M^{-\nicefrac{{1}}{{4}}}\cdot\sqrt{\nicefrac{{\delta}}{{\mu}}}\right)\log\nicefrac{{1}}{{\varepsilon}}\right) communication complexity (Lin etÂ al.,, 2024). In addition, variance reduction turns out to be useful to design methods with compression. There is Three Pillars Algorithm, which achieves ğ’ªâ€‹((1+Mâˆ’1/2â‹…Î´/Î¼)â€‹logâ¡1/Îµ)ğ’ª1â‹…superscriptğ‘€12ğ›¿ğœ‡1ğœ€\mathcal{O}\left(\left(1+M^{-\nicefrac{{1}}{{2}}}\cdot\nicefrac{{\delta}}{{\mu}}\right)\log\nicefrac{{1}}{{\varepsilon}}\right) for variational inequalities (Beznosikov etÂ al.,, 2024).

The weakness of the accelerated variance reduction methods is that they require a small inversely proportional to Mğ‘€\sqrt{M} step size (Beznosikov etÂ al.,, 2024; Khaled and Jin,, 2022; Lin etÂ al.,, 2024). Thus, one has to â€œpayâ€ for the convergence to an arbitrary Îµğœ€\varepsilon-solution by increasing the iteration complexity of the method. However, there is the already mentioned gain in terms of the number of server-node communications. Meanwhile, accelerated versions of the classic SGD do not have this flaw (Vaswani etÂ al.,, 2020). In some regimes, the accuracy that can be achieved without the use of variance reduction may be sufficient, including for distributed problems under similarity conditions.

3Â Â Our Contribution

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet New method. We propose a new method based on the deterministic Accelerated ExtraGradient (AEG) (Kovalev etÂ al.,, 2022). Unlike AEG, we add the ability to sample computational nodes. This saves a significant amount of runtime. As mentioned above, sampling was already implemented in Three Pillars Algorithm (Beznosikov etÂ al.,, 2024), Catalyzed SVRP (Khaled and Jin,, 2022) and AccSVRS (Lin etÂ al.,, 2024). However, this was done using SVRG-like approaches. We rely instead on SGD, which does not require decreasing the step size as the number of computational nodes increases.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Privacy via noise. We consider stochasticity not only in the choice of nodes, but also in the additive noise in the transmission of information from client to server. This makes it much harder to steal private data in the case of an attack on the algorithm.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Theoretical analysis. We show that the Hessian similarity implies gradient one with an additional term. Therefore, it is possible to estimate the variance associated with sampling nodes more optimistically. Thus, in some cases ASEG converges quite accurately before getting "stuck" near the solution.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Analysis of subproblem. We consider different approaches to solving a subproblem that occurs on a server. Our analysis allows us to estimate the number of iterations required to ensure convergence of the method.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Experiments. We validate the constructed theory with numerical experiments on several real datasets.

4Â Â Stochastic Version of Accelerated ExtraGradient

Algorithm 1 (ASEG) is the modification of AEG (Kovalev etÂ al.,, 2022). In one iteration, server communicates with clients twice. In the first round, random machines are selected (Line 6). They perform a computation and send the gradient to the server (Line 15). Then the server solves the local subproblem at Line 16 and the solution is used to compute the stochastic (extra)gradient at the second round of communication (Line 17 and Line 26). This is followed by a gradient step with momentum at Line 27.

Let us briefly summarize the main differences with AEG. Line 16 of Algorithm 1 uses a gradient over the local nodesâ€™ batches, rather than all of them, as is done in the baseline method. Moreover, the case where local gradients are noisy is supported. This is needed for privacy purposes. Similarly in Line 27. Note that we consider the most general case where different devices are involved in solving the subproblem and performing the gradient step.

ASEG requires Î˜â€‹(2â€‹B)Î˜2ğµ\Theta(2B) of communication rounds (Line 15 and Line 26), where BğµB is the number of nodes involved in the iteration. Unlike our method, AEG does Î˜â€‹(2â€‹Mâˆ’2)Î˜2ğ‘€2\Theta(2M-2) per iteration. AccSVRS does Î˜â€‹(2â€‹M)Î˜2ğ‘€\Theta(2M) on average. Thus, in experiments, either the difference between the methods is invisible, or AEG loses. ASEG deals with a local gradient âˆ‡rmâ€‹(x,Î¾)âˆ‡subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ‘¥ğœ‰\nabla r_{m}(x,\xi), which can have the structure:

âˆ‡rmâ€‹(x,Î¾)=âˆ‡rmâ€‹(x)+Î¾,âˆ‡subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ‘¥ğœ‰âˆ‡subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ‘¥ğœ‰\displaystyle\nabla r_{m}(x,\xi)=\nabla r_{m}(x)+\xi,

where, for example, Î¾âˆˆNâ€‹(0,Ïƒ2)ğœ‰ğ‘0superscriptğœ2\xi\in N(0,\sigma^{2}) or Î¾âˆˆUâ€‹(âˆ’c,c)ğœ‰ğ‘ˆğ‘ğ‘\xi\in U(-c,c). This is the previously mentioned additive noise overlay technique, popular in the federated learning.

5Â Â Theoretical Analysis

Before we delve into analysis, let us introduce some definitions and assumptions to build the convergence theory.

In this paper, complexity is understood in the sense of number of server-node communications. This means that we consider how many times a server exchange vectors with clients. In this case, a single contact is counted as one communication.

We work with functions of a class widely used in the literature.

where Î¶â‰¥0ğœ0\zeta\geq 0.

Assumption 2 is a generalization of Proposition 1, where the correction term is multiplied by some constant Î¶ğœ\zeta. Formally, it can take any non-negative value, but it is important to analyze only two cases corresponding to different degrees of similarity: Î¶=0ğœ0\zeta=0 and Î¶=1ğœ1\zeta=1. Indeed, any non-negative values of Î¶ğœ\zeta give asymptotically the same complexity.

A stochastic oracle is available for the function at each node. We impose the standard assumption:

Theorem 4.

Under Assumptions 1 and 3, consider the problem (7) to be solved using SGD. There exists decreasing step sizes Î³tâ‰¤1/2â€‹LAsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘¡12subscriptğ¿ğ´\gamma_{t}\leq\nicefrac{{1}}{{2L_{A}}} such that for Tğ‘‡T iterations we obtain:

ğ”¼â€‹[â€–âˆ‡AÂ¯Î¸kâ€‹(xT)â€–2|sk]â‰¤ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptnormâˆ‡superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ´ğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‡2subscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜absent\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla\bar{A}_{\theta}^{k}(x_{T})\|^{2}|s_{k}]\leq 64â€‹Î¸â€‹LA3â€‹â€–x0âˆ’argâ¡minxâˆˆâ„dâ¡AÂ¯Î¸kâ€‹(x)â€–2â€‹expâ¡{âˆ’T4â€‹LAâ€‹Î¸}+36â€‹LA2â€‹Ïƒ12â€‹Î¸T.64ğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ¿ğ´3superscriptnormsubscriptğ‘¥0subscriptğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ´ğœƒğ‘˜ğ‘¥2ğ‘‡4subscriptğ¿ğ´ğœƒ36superscriptsubscriptğ¿ğ´2superscriptsubscriptğœ12ğœƒğ‘‡\displaystyle 64\theta L_{A}^{3}\left\|x_{0}-\arg\min_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\bar{A}_{\theta}^{k}(x)\right\|^{2}\exp\left\{-\frac{T}{4L_{A}\theta}\right\}+\frac{36L_{A}^{2}\sigma_{1}^{2}\theta}{T}.

In this way, we can achieve optimal convergence rate of SGD. However, we would like to enjoy linear convergence. The idea is to use variance reduction methods.

6.2Â Â SVRG Approach

Another approach to solving the subproblem is to use variance reduction methods, for example, SVRG. Let us take xgksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘”ğ‘˜x_{g}^{k} as a starting point and look at the first epoch. It is known from (Gorbunov etÂ al.,, 2019):

ğ”¼â€‹[AÂ¯Î¸kâ€‹(1Jâ€‹âˆ‘j=1Jxj)âˆ’AÂ¯Î¸kâ€‹(xâˆ—)]â‰¤2â€‹(Î¼âˆ’1+2â€‹Jâ€‹Î³2â€‹LA)Jâ€‹Î³â€‹(1âˆ’2â€‹Î³â€‹LA)â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[AÂ¯Î¸kâ€‹(xgk)âˆ’AÂ¯Î¸kâ€‹(xâˆ—)],ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ´ğœƒğ‘˜1ğ½superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ½subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ´ğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥2superscriptğœ‡12ğ½superscriptğ›¾2subscriptğ¿ğ´ğ½ğ›¾12ğ›¾subscriptğ¿ğ´ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ´ğœƒğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘”ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ´ğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥\mathbb{E}\left[\bar{A}_{\theta}^{k}\left(\frac{1}{J}\sum_{j=1}^{J}x_{j}\right)-\bar{A}_{\theta}^{k}(x_{*})\right]\leq\frac{2(\mu^{-1}+2J\gamma^{2}L_{A})}{J\gamma(1-2\gamma L_{A})}\mathbb{E}\left[\bar{A}_{\theta}^{k}(x_{g}^{k})-\bar{A}_{\theta}^{k}(x_{*})\right],

where Jğ½J is an epoch size. x=1Jâ€‹âˆ‘j=1Jxjğ‘¥1ğ½superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ½subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—x=\frac{1}{J}\sum_{j=1}^{J}x_{j} is the next point after the algorithm finishes current epoch. We can rewrite for Tğ‘‡T-th epoch:

ğ”¼â€‹[AÂ¯Î¸kâ€‹(x^T)âˆ’AÂ¯Î¸kâ€‹(xâˆ—)]â‰¤(2â€‹(Î¼âˆ’1+2â€‹Jâ€‹Î³2â€‹LA)Jâ€‹Î³â€‹(1âˆ’2â€‹Î³â€‹LA))Tâ€‹ğ”¼â€‹[AÂ¯Î¸kâ€‹(xgk)âˆ’AÂ¯Î¸kâ€‹(xâˆ—)].ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ´ğœƒğ‘˜subscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ´ğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥superscript2superscriptğœ‡12ğ½superscriptğ›¾2subscriptğ¿ğ´ğ½ğ›¾12ğ›¾subscriptğ¿ğ´ğ‘‡ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ´ğœƒğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘”ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ´ğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥\mathbb{E}\left[\bar{A}_{\theta}^{k}\left(\widehat{x}_{T}\right)-\bar{A}_{\theta}^{k}(x_{*})\right]\leq\left(\frac{2(\mu^{-1}+2J\gamma^{2}L_{A})}{J\gamma(1-2\gamma L_{A})}\right)^{T}\mathbb{E}\left[\bar{A}_{\theta}^{k}(x_{g}^{k})-\bar{A}_{\theta}^{k}(x_{*})\right].

Then we write strong-convexity property:

ğ”¼â€‹[AÂ¯Î¸kâ€‹(xgk)âˆ’AÂ¯Î¸kâ€‹(xâˆ—)]â‰¤12â€‹Î¼â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[âˆ¥âˆ‡AÂ¯Î¸kâ€‹(xgk)âˆ¥2].ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ´ğœƒğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘”ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ´ğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥12ğœ‡ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ´ğœƒğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘”ğ‘˜2\mathbb{E}\left[\bar{A}_{\theta}^{k}(x_{g}^{k})-\bar{A}_{\theta}^{k}(x_{*})\right]\leq\frac{1}{2\mu}\mathbb{E}[\lVert\nabla\bar{A}_{\theta}^{k}(x_{g}^{k})\rVert^{2}].

Using LAsubscriptğ¿ğ´L_{A}-smoothness of AÂ¯Î¸ksuperscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ´ğœƒğ‘˜\bar{A}_{\theta}^{k}, we obtain

ğ”¼â€‹[âˆ¥âˆ‡AÂ¯Î¸kâ€‹(x^T)âˆ¥2]â‰¤ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ´ğœƒğ‘˜subscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘‡2absent\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left\lVert\nabla\bar{A}_{\theta}^{k}\left(\widehat{x}_{T}\right)\right\rVert^{2}\right]\leq 2â€‹Lâ€‹ğ”¼â€‹[AÂ¯Î¸kâ€‹(x^T)âˆ’AÂ¯Î¸kâ€‹(xâˆ—)]2ğ¿ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ´ğœƒğ‘˜subscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ´ğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥\displaystyle 2L\mathbb{E}\left[\bar{A}_{\theta}^{k}\left(\widehat{x}_{T}\right)-\bar{A}_{\theta}^{k}(x_{*})\right]
â‰¤\displaystyle\leq LAÎ¼â€‹(2â€‹(Î¼âˆ’1+2â€‹Jâ€‹Î³2â€‹LA)Jâ€‹Î³â€‹(1âˆ’2â€‹Î³â€‹LA))Tâ€‹ğ”¼â€‹[âˆ¥âˆ‡AÂ¯Î¸kâ€‹(xgk)âˆ¥2].subscriptğ¿ğ´ğœ‡superscript2superscriptğœ‡12ğ½superscriptğ›¾2subscriptğ¿ğ´ğ½ğ›¾12ğ›¾subscriptğ¿ğ´ğ‘‡ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ´ğœƒğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘”ğ‘˜2\displaystyle\frac{L_{A}}{\mu}\left(\frac{2(\mu^{-1}+2J\gamma^{2}L_{A})}{J\gamma(1-2\gamma L_{A})}\right)^{T}\mathbb{E}[\lVert\nabla\bar{A}_{\theta}^{k}(x_{g}^{k})\rVert^{2}].

Thus, for a suitable combination of epoch size and step, we expect to obtain linear convergence of the subproblem, which is consistent with the experimental results.

6.3Â Â Loopless Approach

In this section, we filling in some gaps in subproblem analysis. Decision criterion for ASEG is (4). Let us assume that we obtained:

â€–âˆ‡AÎ¸kâ€‹(xT)â€–2=ğ’ªâ€‹(1TÎ±),Î±>0.formulae-sequencesuperscriptnormâˆ‡superscriptsubscriptğ´ğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‡2ğ’ª1superscriptğ‘‡ğ›¼ğ›¼0||\nabla A_{\theta}^{k}(x_{T})||^{2}=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{T^{\alpha}}\right),\quad\alpha>0. (8)

We use this to obtain a lower bound on Tğ‘‡T. The important question is whether it is possible to take fewer steps so that the criterion necessary for the convergence of the whole algorithm is met. In other words, we want to check whether the loopless version of ASEG turns out to be better than the usual one, as in the case of SVRG and KATYUSHA (Kovalev etÂ al.,, 2020).

We are interested in comparing deterministic and random choices of Tğ‘‡T. Let Î¾ğœ‰\xi be a random variable describing the number of steps. Î¾ğœ‰\xi takes positive discrete values. Let Ağ´A be the number of steps for the subproblem of ASEG, defined deterministically and satisfying (4). Let us assume that

1Î¾Î±â‰¤1AÎ±.1superscriptğœ‰ğ›¼1superscriptğ´ğ›¼\frac{1}{\xi^{\alpha}}\leq\frac{1}{A^{\alpha}}. (9)

Then from (8) we know that

â€–âˆ‡AÎ¸kâ€‹(xÎ¾)â€–2â‰¤â€–âˆ‡AÎ¸kâ€‹(xA)â€–2,superscriptnormâˆ‡superscriptsubscriptğ´ğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğœ‰2superscriptnormâˆ‡superscriptsubscriptğ´ğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ´2\|\nabla A_{\theta}^{k}(x_{\xi})\|^{2}\leq\|\nabla A_{\theta}^{k}(x_{A})\|^{2},

where xÎ¾subscriptğ‘¥ğœ‰x_{\xi} is the point obtained through Î¾ğœ‰\xi solver steps. Obviously, the reverse is also true. In other words, the condition (9) is the criterion for Î¾ğœ‰\xi to solve the initial subproblem. At the same time, we want to minimize ğ”¼â€‹Î¾ğ”¼ğœ‰\mathbb{E}\xi to take as few steps as possible.

Proposition 2.

ğ”¼â€‹[Î¾]<Aâ‡’ğ”¼â€‹[1Î¾Î±]>1AÎ±ğ”¼delimited-[]ğœ‰ğ´â‡’ğ”¼delimited-[]1superscriptğœ‰ğ›¼1superscriptğ´ğ›¼\mathbb{E}[\xi]<A\Rightarrow\mathbb{E}[\frac{1}{\xi^{\alpha}}]>\frac{1}{A^{\alpha}}.

Proof.

Let pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i} be the probability to choose Î¾=iğœ‰ğ‘–\xi=i. Then we have

ğ”¼â€‹[1Î¾Î±]=âˆ‘i=1Tpiâ€‹1iÎ±.ğ”¼delimited-[]1superscriptğœ‰ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1superscriptğ‘–ğ›¼\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{\xi^{\alpha}}\right]=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{T}p_{i}\frac{1}{i^{\alpha}}.

Since Î±>0ğ›¼0\alpha>0, Ï•â€‹(i)=1/iÎ±italic-Ï•ğ‘–1superscriptğ‘–ğ›¼\phi(i)=\nicefrac{{1}}{{i^{\alpha}}} is a convex function. Using the Jensenâ€™s inequality, we obtain

ğ”¼â€‹[1Î¾Î±]â‰¥1(ğ”¼â€‹Î¾)Î±>1AÎ±.ğ”¼delimited-[]1superscriptğœ‰ğ›¼1superscriptğ”¼ğœ‰ğ›¼1superscriptğ´ğ›¼\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{\xi^{\alpha}}\right]\geq\frac{1}{(\mathbb{E}\xi)^{\alpha}}>\frac{1}{A^{\alpha}}.

âˆ

Thus, in the worst case, if the expectation of Î¾ğœ‰\xi is less than the deterministic number of iterations, the criterion cannot be met and there is no probabilistic method of choosing the number of iterations that is better than the deterministic one.

It is worth noting that the same can be said about a pair of SVRG and L-SVRG. It is obvious that SVRG could be reduced to L-SVRG if the number of iterations before updating the gradient is considered as a random variable. Thus, the epoch Jğ½J is from the geometric distribution and one can compare which algorithm gives a more accurate solution after performing the inner loop. For SVRG-rate we have (Gorbunov etÂ al.,, 2020):

ğ”¼ğ”¼\displaystyle\mathbb{E} [AÂ¯Î¸kâ€‹(xJâ€‹(t+1))âˆ’AÂ¯Î¸kâ€‹(xâˆ—)]â‰¤(1Î·â€‹Î³â€‹(1âˆ’2â€‹Lâ€‹Î³)â€‹J+2â€‹Lâ€‹Î³1âˆ’2â€‹Lâ€‹Î³)â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[AÂ¯Î¸kâ€‹(xJâ€‹t)âˆ’AÂ¯Î¸kâ€‹(xâˆ—)],delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ´ğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ½ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ´ğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥1ğœ‚ğ›¾12ğ¿ğ›¾ğ½2ğ¿ğ›¾12ğ¿ğ›¾ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ´ğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ½ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ´ğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥\displaystyle\left[\bar{A}_{\theta}^{k}(x_{J(t+1)})-\bar{A}_{\theta}^{k}(x_{*})\right]\leq\left(\frac{1}{\eta\gamma(1-2L\gamma)J}+\frac{2L\gamma}{1-2L\gamma}\right)\mathbb{E}\left[\bar{A}_{\theta}^{k}(x_{Jt})-\bar{A}_{\theta}^{k}(x_{*})\right], (10)

where Î³ğ›¾\gamma is a step and Î·>0ğœ‚0\eta>0 - some constant. From the Proposition 2 and (10) we obtain:

(1Î·â€‹Î³â€‹(1âˆ’2â€‹Lâ€‹Î³)â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[1J]+2â€‹Lâ€‹Î³1âˆ’2â€‹Lâ€‹Î³)â‰¤(1Î·â€‹Î³â€‹(1âˆ’2â€‹Lâ€‹Î³)â€‹J+2â€‹Lâ€‹Î³1âˆ’2â€‹Lâ€‹Î³).1ğœ‚ğ›¾12ğ¿ğ›¾ğ”¼delimited-[]1ğ½2ğ¿ğ›¾12ğ¿ğ›¾1ğœ‚ğ›¾12ğ¿ğ›¾ğ½2ğ¿ğ›¾12ğ¿ğ›¾\left(\frac{1}{\eta\gamma(1-2L\gamma)}\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{J}\right]+\frac{2L\gamma}{1-2L\gamma}\right)\leq\left(\frac{1}{\eta\gamma(1-2L\gamma)J}+\frac{2L\gamma}{1-2L\gamma}\right).

Thus, in the worst case, loopless versions converges no faster than usual ones.

7Â Â Numerical Experiments

To support theoretical analysis and insights, we solve both logistic regression problem:

râ€‹(x)=1Mâ€‹âˆ‘m=1M1nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nlnâ¡(1+eâˆ’bjmâ€‹âŸ¨x,ajmâŸ©)+Î»â€‹â€–xâ€–2,ğ‘Ÿğ‘¥1ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ‘€1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘›1superscriptğ‘’subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘—ğœ†superscriptnormğ‘¥2r(x)=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{m=1}^{M}\frac{1}{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}\ln\left(1+e^{-b^{m}_{j}\left\langle x,a^{m}_{j}\right\rangle}\right)+\lambda\|x\|^{2},

and quadratic regression problem:

râ€‹(x)=1Mâ€‹âˆ‘m=1M1nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1n(âŸ¨x,ajmâŸ©âˆ’bjm)2+Î»â€‹â€–xâ€–2.ğ‘Ÿğ‘¥1ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ‘€1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘›superscriptğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘—2ğœ†superscriptnormğ‘¥2r(x)=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{m=1}^{M}\frac{1}{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}\left(\langle x,a^{m}_{j}\rangle-b^{m}_{j}\right)^{2}+\lambda\|x\|^{2}.

Here xğ‘¥x refers to parameters of the model, ajmsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘ša_{j}^{m} is the feature description and bjmsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘šb_{j}^{m} is the corresponding label. To avoid overfitting, we use l2subscriptğ‘™2{l_{2}}-regularization. The penalty parameter Î»ğœ†\lambda is set to L/100ğ¿100\nicefrac{{L}}{{100}}, where Lğ¿L is a smoothness constant (2). We use SVRG and SARAH as the subtask solvers in Algorithm 1. In all tests, the original datasets are merged into batches {rb}i=1M+Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘–1ğ‘€ğ‘\left\{r_{b}\right\}_{i=1}^{M+N}. A function r1â€‹(x)subscriptğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘¥r_{1}(x) is created from part of the acquired ones:

r1â€‹(x)=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘b=1Nrbâ€‹(x),N<M.formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘¥1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘1ğ‘subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘€r_{1}(x)=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{b=1}^{N}r_{b}(x),\quad N<M.

Due to the Hessian similarity, we have the following expression for the smoothness constant

âˆ¥âˆ‡2râ€‹(x)âˆ’âˆ‡2r1â€‹(x)âˆ¥â‰¤Î´,delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptâˆ‡2ğ‘Ÿğ‘¥superscriptâˆ‡2subscriptğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘¥ğ›¿\lVert\nabla^{2}r(x)-\nabla^{2}r_{1}(x)\rVert\leq\delta,

where

râ€‹(x)=1Mâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Mriâ€‹(x).ğ‘Ÿğ‘¥1ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘¥r(x)=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{i=1}^{M}r_{i}(x).

Then for the quadratic task we have

Î´=âˆ¥1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1NAiâˆ’1Mâ€‹âˆ‘j=1MAjâˆ¥.ğ›¿delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ´ğ‘–1ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘€subscriptğ´ğ‘—\delta=\left\lVert\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}A_{i}-\frac{1}{M}\sum_{j=1}^{M}A_{j}\right\rVert.

For the logistic regression, Î´ğ›¿\delta is estimated by enumerating 100 points in the neighborhood of the solution. In both cases, obtained value is multiplied by 3/232\nicefrac{{3}}{{2}}. Experiments are performed on three datasets: Mushrooms, W8A, A9A, (Chang and Lin,, 2011).

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet We investigate how the size of the batches affects the convergence of ASEG on tasks with different parameters. Figure 1 shows the dependence of untuned ASEG convergence on the batch size. In the first experiment the method on 505050 nodes solves the problem with Î¼=0.105ğœ‡0.105\mu=0.105 and Î´=1.45ğ›¿1.45\delta=1.45. According to Corollary 2 one should choose B>72â‹…(Î´/Î¼)3/2â‰ˆ3695ğµâ‹…72superscriptğ›¿ğœ‡323695B>72\cdot(\nicefrac{{\delta}}{{\mu}})^{\nicefrac{{3}}{{2}}}\approx 3695 to obtain optimal complexity. That is, for any size of the batch, there is non-optimal rate. In the second experiment, the method on 200200200 nodes solves the problem with Î¼=0.06ğœ‡0.06\mu=0.06, Î´=0.07ğ›¿0.07\delta=0.07. In this case, ASEG has guaranteed optimal complexity for B>57ğµ57B>57 and converges to rather small values of the criterion.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet We compare ASEG to AccSVRS (Figure 2 and Figure 3). 50 nodes are available for Mushrooms and 200 nodes are available for A9A. If the ratio between Î¼ğœ‡\mu, Î´ğ›¿\delta, and BğµB yields the optimal complexity according to Corollary 2, then due to similarity there is an optimistic estimate on the batching noise provides a significant gain over AccSVRS. Otherwise, it is worth using full batching and obtaining a less appreciable gain.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet In ASEG stability experiments (Figure 4, Figure 5, Figure 6, Figure 7) it is tested how white noise in each âˆ‡rmâ€‹(x)âˆ‡subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ‘¥\nabla r_{m}(x) affects the convergence. It can be seen that increasing the randomness does not worsen the convergence. This can be explained by the fact that the convergence is mainly determined by accuracy of chosen solver.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet ASEG experiments test how changing the epoch size changes the ASEG and subproblem (Line 16 of Algorithm 1) convergence with SVRG and SARAH solvers (Figure 8, Figure 9, Figure 10, Figure 11, Figure 12, Figure 13, Figure 14, Figure 15).

8Â Â Conclusion

Based on the SGD-like approach, we have adapted Accelerated ExtraGradient to solve Federated Learning problems by adding two stochasticities: sampling of computational nodes and application of noise to local gradients. Numerical experiments show that for small values of Î´/Î¼ğ›¿ğœ‡\nicefrac{{\delta}}{{\mu}} or a sufficiently large number of available nodes, Algorithm 1 (ASEG) is significantly superior to accelerated variance reduction methods (Figure 3), which is consistent with the theory (Corollary 1). If the problem parameters are not "good" enough, there is a Î´2/(Î¼2â€‹M)â‹…logâ¡1/Îµâ‹…superscriptğ›¿2superscriptğœ‡2ğ‘€1ğœ€\nicefrac{{\delta^{2}}}{{(\mu^{2}M)}}\cdot\log\nicefrac{{1}}{{\varepsilon}} term in the communication complexity of batched ASEG (Corollary 2). Nevertheless, the superiority in the number of communications remains even in this case (Figure 2, Figure 3). Experiments also show the robustness of our method against noise (Figure 4, Figure 5, Figure 6, Figure 7). The server subproblem has also been studied numerically (Figure 10, Figure 11, Figure 14, Figure 15) and theoretically. The analysis shows the inefficiency of randomly choosing the number of solver iterations for the internal subtask (Proposition 2).
